column4: can anyone tell me how to navigate to a file, rather than a directory?
clarify what you mean.
that makes little sence...   what do you mean by navigate?
well im jsut following the directions i found online, where they use navigate all the time
cant say taht ive ever seen that term to  open a file.. You navigate  - ie :  'move to' a directory then work on files in the dir...
well i guess i just meant, how do i navigate to the apple pie
that would be going to the directory/folder.. with the use of the 'cd' command.
yes i see the difference, but you see what i meant. after all your a doctor. it was just an issue of semantics.
semantics kills :)
i still use the term 'directory' not folder.. also.. im old-skool
you were allready navigating to the file :) is what had us confused.
yes, im new to command line, its what had me confused, i thought i could make the file my working directory jsut as i would /Desktop, for example.
more fun confusion at the 'lowest' levels of the OS.. even directories are files. :)
actually, while were at it, how do i connect to a network (aka, the windows network at my apartment) in ubuntu. i can see the other connected computers but i cant access any files

depends.. :) the 'new' way is use the gnome file manager and browse the network/acces the shares.. the  command line way is to mount the samba shares with smbmount or similer commands.  see the pacakge 'samba-doc' and the books in it.. for all the info you would EVER want on samba. :)

also the gnome/file manager/browse method - is VERY flakey for me.. often i have to type in the full path to the  machine/sharename for it to pop up the username/password dialog to allow me to access the share
now using samba?
Huh?
i have samba. but i have no idea what to do with it, im reading something from a google search right now.
tell the channel exactly what it is you are wanting to do. :) mounting samba shares via the command line - is documented all over the place..
do you know if mount name is going to be the name of the computer, for example HTPC is the name?
monting basics.. the mount POINT is a directory - that can be ANY name you want
